0.92.text:
Sophie: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English.
I'm Sophie.

4.46.text:
Neil: And I'm Neil. Sophie, did you see the
beautiful sky last night?

8.98.text: Sophie: No, I went to bed early. Why?

11.18.text:
Neil: I was wondering if there was life out
there.

14.90.text:
Sophie: You mean life on other planets? That's
just science fiction, Neil.

19.04.text:
Neil: It isn't! People are fascinated by life
on other planets for a good reason.

23.56.text: Sophie: You believe in little green men?

28.60.text:
Sophie: Well, Mars is our closest neighbour
in the solar system

31.82.text: and the subject of today's show.

34.50.text:
And that brings me on to our usual quiz question.
How long is a day on Mars?

39.48.text:
Is it about... a) 5 hours?
b) 25 hours?

47.06.text:
Neil: And I think it must be c) 45 hours.
Things are weird on other planets.

53.20.text:
And Mars is further from the sun than us...
Mars may be our closest neighbour, but it's

59.36.text: hardly in our backyard, is it?

60.93.text: Sophie: It is in astronomical terms, Neil

63.39.text: it's visible to the naked eye

71.14.text:
Well, we'll find out later on in the show
whether you got the answer right or not.

75.88.text:
Now can you tell me Neil why people like you
get excited about the possibility of life on Mars?

82.08.text:
Neil: Well, Mars is similar to the Earth in
some important ways

85.38.text: which means if life developed on our planet, why not Mars?

89.39.text:
Sophie: That's true. Its temperature is in
the right zone

92.39.text: not too hot and not too cold.

95.78.text: But actually we could find Mars pretty cold

99.44.text: an average temperature would be around minus 63 degrees Celsius compared to Earth's 14 degrees Celsius.

107.66.text: It's also very arid – or dry.

110.40.text:
Neil: And it needs to be wet for life to develop,
doesn't it?

114.02.text:
Sophie: That's right. Many scientists think
that liquid water is essential for life!

118.90.text:
But there may have been water on the surface
of Mars in the past.

122.74.text:
And recent research suggests that there may
be water underground.

127.42.text:
Let's hear some more about this from Professor
John Zarnecki,

130.80.text: who teaches Space Science at The Open University.

134.58.text:
John Zarnecki: We are now seeing that in fact
Mars probably does have water – not liquid water

139.66.text: that there is ice just below the surface

143.08.text: and there's even just recently tantalizing evidence that perhaps water does flow periodically...

148.80.text:
Now, and also coupled with the fact that here
on Earth we're finding that life in very primitive form

155.16.text:
exists in the most extreme environments,
these are the so called 'extremophiles'

159.64.text: that exist at the bottom of the oceans...

161.65.text: So life is much, much tougher.

164.26.text: Neil: What does tantalizing mean, Sophie?

166.34.text:
Sophie: It means something you want that's
almost, but not quite, within reach.

171.18.text:
So, scientists would love to think water flows
on Mars

174.92.text: but the evidence isn't strong enough for this to be certain.

178.74.text:
The other interesting point the professor
makes

181.56.text: is that life may exist in the very harsh Martian environment

185.74.text: because primitive life exists in extreme places on Earth.

190.48.text:
Neil: Extremophiles are organisms – or
small creatures

193.84.text: that live in very extreme environments

195.94.text: and can survive conditions that would kill most other organisms.

199.52.text: But on Mars they would be living underground

202.16.text: because the radiation – or light and heat

205.38.text:
from the Sun would kill any organisms
living on the surface of the planet.

210.36.text:
So why doesn't the Sun's radiation kill us
then, Sophie?

213.76.text:
Sophie: The Earth has a strong magnetic field
created by its hot molten core or centre ...

219.86.text:
and this protects us from the Sun's harmful
solar winds.

223.58.text:
Neil: And what about Mars - why doesn't it
have a magnetic field?

227.24.text: Sophie: It used to ... 4 billion years ago.

230.44.text:
It's possible that a massive collision with
an asteroid

233.80.text: might have heated up Mars's core, disrupting the magnetic fields.

238.02.text:
Neil: And if you disrupt a process you stop
it from continuing normally.

242.22.text:
Now, to return to the subject of collisions,
Sophie, I have something very interesting to tell you.

249.16.text: Neil: A meteorite – or a piece of rock from outer space – might've crashed into the Earth millions of years ago.

256.46.text:
That meteorite might have contained Martian
life forms.

263.92.text: So we might be descended from Martians!

269.26.text:
Sophie: That's actually an interesting idea,
Neil.

271.85.text:
But let's listen to Professor John Zarnecki
talking about interplanetary life.

277.64.text:
John Zarnecki: If we do find traces of life
on Mars we don't know, do we

282.86.text: whether it evolved independently or was it perhaps seeded from Earth.

286.16.text:
It is possible that life forms from Earth
travelled to Mars and perhaps existed there

292.76.text: Neil: So life on Mars may have evolved – or developed – on its own.

297.04.text:
Or it might have arrived from Earth in a lump
of rock... Or the other way round!

301.72.text:
So Martians might be humans or we might be
Martians!

305.54.text: One big interplanetary happy family, Sophie!

308.36.text:
Sophie: Well Neil, let's hope you stay happy
after you hear the answer to today's quiz question.

313.58.text: I asked: How long is a day on Mars? Is it ... a) 5 hours? b) 25 hours? Or c) 45 hours?

322.38.text:
Neil: And I said c) 45 hours – they must
have a long day over there.

329.00.text:
The correct answer is b) because a day on
Mars is slightly longer than here on Earth

336.20.text:
Anyway, can we at least hear the words we
learned today?

353.62.text:
Sophie: Well, that's the end of today's 6
Minute English.
